content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. The <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein has been reported to increase the growth of certain types of cancer cells. Researchers studying the metabolism and development of stomach cancer cells investigated the potential role of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein in these cells. In the first investigation, the researchers quantified the relative amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in normal stomach cells and in each of four different lines of stomach cancer cells (Figure 1). Using data from a group of <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> patients with stomach cancer, the researchers also analyzed the relative amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein detected in samples of the cancer cells and in normal cells immediately adjacent to the cancer cells (Figure 2). Figure 1. <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein levels in normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and stomach cancer cell lines from four different patients (<math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-4</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), shown relative to the level in normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure 2. The number of patients, from <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> tested, whose stomach cancer cells or normal stomach cells adjacent to the cancer cells express high, low, or no <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein In the second investigation, the researchers grew four groups of stomach cells in petri dishes containing nutrient broth: • <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, normal stomach cells• <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a line of stomach cancer cells that the researchers had examined for <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> expression• <math alttext="S C plus R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> line of stomach cancer cells to which a plasmid was added that encodes a small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> complementary to a portion of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. When these small <math alttext="R N A's" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bind to the complementary portion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is broken down rather than translated.•<math alttext="S C plus plasmid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> , the <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> line of stomach cancer cells to which a plasmid was added that does NOT encode the complementary small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> After <math alttext="24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>24</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> hours of growth, the researchers measured several indicators of metabolism by an equal number of all four cell groups: glucose uptake, lactic acid production, and the level of cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production in the presence of a compound that blocks the electron transport chain (Figure 3). The values were calculated relative to the values obtained for normal stomach cells. Figure 3. Glucose uptake, lactic acid production, and cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> levels in stomach cells. <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, normal stomach cells; <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, stomach cancer cells; <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>SC + plasmid</mtext></mrow></math>, <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with added plasmid only; <math alttext="S C plus R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with added plasmid encoding small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> complementary to a portion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Explain why the amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in normal stomach (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ) cells might be different from the amount in normal liver cells, even though both contain two copies of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SIRT3</mtext></mrow></math> gene.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. The <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein has been reported to increase the growth of certain types of cancer cells. Researchers studying the metabolism and development of stomach cancer cells investigated the potential role of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein in these cells. In the first investigation, the researchers quantified the relative amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in normal stomach cells and in each of four different lines of stomach cancer cells (Figure 1). Using data from a group of <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> patients with stomach cancer, the researchers also analyzed the relative amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein detected in samples of the cancer cells and in normal cells immediately adjacent to the cancer cells (Figure 2). Figure 1. <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein levels in normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and stomach cancer cell lines from four different patients (<math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-4</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), shown relative to the level in normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure 2. The number of patients, from <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> tested, whose stomach cancer cells or normal stomach cells adjacent to the cancer cells express high, low, or no <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein In the second investigation, the researchers grew four groups of stomach cells in petri dishes containing nutrient broth: • <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, normal stomach cells• <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a line of stomach cancer cells that the researchers had examined for <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> expression• <math alttext="S C plus R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> line of stomach cancer cells to which a plasmid was added that encodes a small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> complementary to a portion of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. When these small <math alttext="R N A's" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bind to the complementary portion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is broken down rather than translated.•<math alttext="S C plus plasmid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> , the <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> line of stomach cancer cells to which a plasmid was added that does NOT encode the complementary small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> After <math alttext="24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>24</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> hours of growth, the researchers measured several indicators of metabolism by an equal number of all four cell groups: glucose uptake, lactic acid production, and the level of cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production in the presence of a compound that blocks the electron transport chain (Figure 3). The values were calculated relative to the values obtained for normal stomach cells. Figure 3. Glucose uptake, lactic acid production, and cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> levels in stomach cells. <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, normal stomach cells; <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, stomach cancer cells; <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>SC + plasmid</mtext></mrow></math>, <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with added plasmid only; <math alttext="S C plus R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with added plasmid encoding small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> complementary to a portion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Explain why the amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in normal stomach (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ) cells might be different from the amount in normal liver cells, even though both contain two copies of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SIRT3</mtext></mrow></math> gene.

(b) Identify an independent variable in the researchers' experiment shown in Figure 3. Justify the inclusion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein expression in adjacent normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) as part of the data collection and analysis process in the investigation shown in Figure 2. Based on the data in Figures 1 and 3, describe the relationship between <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> expression and lactic acid production. Calculate the percent change in relative uptake of glucose by <math alttext="S C plus R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells compared with <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells.

(c) Researchers analyzing the <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene sequence engineer a <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene that is identical to the normal gene except that it lacks the start codon. The researchers introduce this gene into normal stomach cells to determine how much <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> AND protein will be expressed from the engineered <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene in comparison with the amount of <math alttext="m R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and protein expressed from the normal <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene in these cells. Predict the results of this experiment. To support the hypothesis that <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> overexpression causes the measured change in cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production, researchers compared the data from <math alttext="S C plus R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="N S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="S C 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells. Provide reasoning to justify the claim that this comparison provides more conclusive support than does comparing the data from only the <math alttext="N S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="S C 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells. Based on the data in Figure 3, predict the change in the glucose metabolic pathway that allows cells to continue to produce <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> even when they are treated with the compound that blocks the electron transport chain.

(d) Based on the data provided, explain how a drug that reduces <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene expression in cells could be an effective antitumor treatment in stomach cancer. A mutation in the gene encoding a growth factor receptor on human stomach cells results in a receptor that is active, even in the absence of ligand binding. Explain why the cells with the mutant gene will most likely change from normal cells into cancer cells.

skill.text: 1.C: Explain biological concepts and processes in applied contexts.
